content:
Peripheral neuropathy: Causes, symptoms and treatments

Peripheral neuropathy causes weakness, numbness and pain in the periphery such as the hands and feet and can also affect other internal organs such as the digestive tract and circulation. Doctor, Doctor II Vo Don, Department of Neurology, Tam Anh General Hospital, said that understanding the disease can help people prevent, diagnose and treat promptly and effectively, avoiding serious complications.
Peripheral neuropathy causes weakness, numbness and pain in the periphery such as the hands and feet and can also affect internal organs.

What is peripheral neuropathy?
The peripheral nervous system (HTKNB) is a part of the nervous system, including the nucleus and cranial nerves, anterior horn cells of the spinal cord, nerve ganglia outside the brain and spinal canal, roots and nerve branches. spinal nerves, nerve plexuses, peripheral nerves. The main function of the internal nervous system is to link the central nervous system with the limbs and organs. Unlike the central nervous system, the central nervous system is not protected by the spine and skull or the blood-brain barrier, so it is susceptible to the effects of toxins and mechanical damage from the outside.
Peripheral neuropathy is not a separate condition. It is a general term for a number of diseases caused by damage to the body's peripheral nervous system.(1)
The body's nervous system is made up of two parts:
Central nervous system (CNS: central nervous system) includes the brain and spinal cord.; The peripheral nervous system (PNS: peripheral nervous system) connects nerves originating from the brain and spinal cord to the rest of the body such as the upper limbs (arms, forearms, hands); Lower extremities (thighs, legs, feet); Internal organs in the body, joints and even the mouth, eyes, ears, nose and skin.
Peripheral neuropathy occurs when nerves are damaged or destroyed by a variety of mechanisms and are unable to send messages from the brain and spinal cord to the muscles, skin, other parts of the body, and vice versa.
Peripheral neuropathy can affect multiple nerves on both sides (bilateral asymmetric nerve damage, polyneuropathy), symmetric damage, or just one nerve or group of nerves. nerve (mononeuropathy) at one time.
Sciatica is often the result of damage to a nerve or group of nerves due to trauma, localized compression, prolonged pressure or inflammation, such as:
Carpal tunnel syndrome (pain and numbness in the hands and fingers, often related to work due to repetitive wrist compression causing nerve compression).; Peripheral seventh nerve paralysis (also called peripheral facial paralysis or Bell's palsy).

Symptoms of peripheral neuropathy
Each nerve in the peripheral system has a distinct function, so symptoms of the disease will depend on each peripheral nerve affected. Nerves are classified into:(3)
Sensory nerves receive sensations, such as temperature, pain, vibration or touch, from the skin.; Motor nerves control muscle movement; Mixed nerves control both movement and sensation; The autonomic/autonomic nerves control functions such as blood pressure, sweating, heart rate, digestion and bladder function.
Accordingly, symptoms of peripheral neuropathy may include:
Feeling of wearing “gloves” or “wearing socks”.; Burning or sharp pain; Stinging or electric shock-like pain when the skin is irritated; Difficulty sleeping due to tired and sore feet; Loss of balance and coordination; Muscle weakness; Muscle spasms/twitches; Difficulty walking or moving your arms; Abnormal sweating; Abnormalities in blood pressure or fast or slow pulse; Dry, pale green skin
Symptoms include weakness in the limbs such as not being able to hold anything, feeling like your feet are peeling or not being able to recognize when touching the ground or wearing slippers, and feeling pain like being stabbed or burned in your hands and feet. may be common signs and symptoms of peripheral neuropathy.
Neurological disease, also known as neurological disorder, is a disease that affects the nerves, brain, roots, plexuses, etc. It is necessary to understand the causes, symptoms and treatment of the disease.

Causes/factors/risks of peripheral neuropathy
Peripheral neuropathy is nerve damage caused by a number of different diseases. Health conditions that can cause peripheral neuropathy include:(2)
Autoimmune diseases: Includes Sjogren's syndrome, lupus, rheumatoid arthritis, Guillain-Barre syndrome, chronic demyelinating polyneuropathy, and vasculitis.; Autoimmune diseases: Includes Sjogren's syndrome, lupus, rheumatoid arthritis, Guillain-Barre syndrome, chronic demyelinating polyneuropathy, and vasculitis.
Diabetes: Diabetic peripheral neuropathy affects nearly 50% of adults with diabetes and often causes serious complications such as foot ulcers and lower limb amputations.; Diabetes: Diabetic peripheral neuropathy affects nearly 50% of adults with diabetes and often causes serious complications such as foot ulcers and lower limb amputations.
Infections: Includes certain viral or bacterial infections such as Lyme disease, shingles, Epstein-Barr virus, hepatitis B and C, leprosy, diphtheria, and HIV.; Infections: Includes certain viral or bacterial infections such as Lyme disease, shingles, Epstein-Barr virus, hepatitis B and C, leprosy, diphtheria, and HIV.
Genetic disorders: Disorders such as Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease are inherited neurological diseases; Genetic disorders: Disorders such as Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease are inherited neurological diseases.
Tumors: The growth of benign or malignant (cancerous) tumors can cause nerve compression. In addition, polyneuropathy can arise due to certain cancers related to the body's immune response. This is a type of degenerative disorder called paraneoplastic syndrome.; Tumors: The growth of benign or malignant (cancerous) tumors can cause nerve compression. In addition, polyneuropathy can arise due to certain cancers related to the body's immune response. This is a type of degenerative disorder called paraneoplastic syndrome.
Bone marrow disorders: Include an abnormal protein in the blood (monoclonal gammopathies), a form of bone cancer (myeloma), lymphoma, and the rare disease amyloidosis.; Bone marrow disorders: Include an abnormal protein in the blood (monoclonal gammopathies), a form of bone cancer (myeloma), lymphoma and the rare disease amyloidosis.
Other diseases: Including kidney disease, liver disease, connective tissue disorders and kidney failure.; Other diseases: Includes kidney disease, liver disease, connective tissue disorders and kidney failure.
Peripheral neuropathy can also have other causes including:
Chronic alcoholism: Chronic alcoholism can lead to peripheral neuropathy.; Chronic alcoholism: Chronic alcoholism can lead to peripheral neuropathy.
Exposure to toxins: Toxic substances including industrial chemicals and heavy metals such as lead and mercury can cause nerve damage.; Exposure to toxins: Toxic substances including industrial chemicals and heavy metals such as lead and mercury can cause nerve damage.
Taking medications: Some medications, especially those used to treat cancer (chemotherapy) and HIV/AIDS, can cause peripheral neuropathy.; Taking medications: Some medications, especially those used to treat cancer (chemotherapy) and HIV/AIDS, can cause peripheral neuropathy.
Damage or pressure on nerves: Injuries, such as motor vehicle accidents, falls, or sports injuries, can sever or damage peripheral nerves. Nerve pressure can also be caused by wearing a cast or using crutches or repeating a movement such as tapping over and over.; Damage or pressure on nerves: Injuries, such as motor vehicle accidents, falls, or sports injuries, can sever or damage peripheral nerves. Nerve pressure can also be caused by wearing a cast or using crutches or repeating a movement such as tapping over and over.
Vitamin deficiency: B vitamins, especially vitamins B1, B6, B12; vitamin E and niacin are important for nerve health. A deficiency of these vitamins in the body can cause peripheral neuropathy; Vitamin deficiency: B vitamins, especially vitamins B1, B6, B12; vitamin E and niacin are important for nerve health. A deficiency in these vitamins in the body can cause peripheral neuropathy.
However, in some cases, even with extensive evaluation, the cause of peripheral neuropathy in some people remains unknown – this is called idiopathic neuropathy.

Complications of peripheral neuropathy
Complications of peripheral neuropathy may include:
Burns and skin wounds: The patient may not feel temperature changes or pain on frostbitten parts of the body.; Burns and skin wounds: People may not feel temperature changes or pain on frostbitten parts of the body.
Infection: Feet and other areas lacking sensation may be injured without the patient knowing. Doctor Vo Don advises that patients should check these areas regularly and treat small wounds to avoid infection, especially in patients with diabetes.; Infection: Feet and other areas lacking sensation may be injured without the patient knowing. Dr. Vo Don advises that patients should check these areas regularly and treat small wounds to avoid infection, especially in patients with diabetes.
Falls: Weakness and loss of feeling in the limbs can make the patient susceptible to losing balance and falling.; Falls: Weakness and loss of feeling in the limbs can make the patient more likely to lose balance and fall.
People with peripheral neuropathy are prone to falls due to loss of balance, so they need to pay close attention in daily life

Diagnosis method of peripheral neuropathy
Before diagnosing peripheral neuropathy, your doctor will review your medical history and conduct a physical exam to evaluate your nerves. After a neurological evaluation, depending on the symptoms and results of the neurological evaluation, the patient may have other tests that help the doctor determine the type of peripheral neuropathy including:
Neuromuscular electromyography: Electromyography can show problems with how the body's nerve signals travel to the muscles. For this test, the doctor will place a small needle into the patient's muscle. Then, the doctor will ask the patient to gently move the muscles. The probe in the needle will measure the amount of electricity moving through the patient's muscles, from which the doctor can determine whether there is nerve damage, the extent of the damage, and the type of disease causing the damage.; Neuromuscular electromyography: Electromyography can show problems with how the body's nerve signals travel to the muscles. For this test, the doctor will place a small needle into the patient's muscle. Then, the doctor will ask the patient to gently move the muscles. The probe in the needle will measure the amount of electricity moving through the patient's muscles, from which the doctor can determine whether there is nerve damage, the extent of the damage, and the type of disease causing the damage.
Blood tests: Blood tests can measure vitamin and blood sugar levels, and determine whether the patient's thyroid gland is functioning normally. Depending on the condition and cause of the disease, the doctor may prescribe additional blood tests such as: Vitamin B12 and folate content; Thyroid, liver and kidney function; Evaluation of vasculitis; Blood sugar; Antibodies to nerve C components; HIV AIDS; Hepatitis C and B, Genetics.; Blood tests: Blood tests can measure vitamin and blood sugar levels, and determine whether the patient's thyroid gland is functioning normally. Depending on the condition and cause of the disease, the doctor may prescribe additional blood tests such as: Vitamin B12 and folate content; Thyroid, liver and kidney function; Evaluation of vasculitis; Blood sugar; Antibodies to nerve C components; HIV AIDS; Hepatitis C and B, Genetics.
Nerve biopsy: This is a minor procedure that involves removing a small amount of nerve tissue for examination under a microscope.; Nerve biopsy: This is a minor procedure that involves removing a small amount of nerve tissue to examine under a microscope.
Lumbar puncture: This method is performed by the doctor placing electrodes on the patient's skin. They then pulse a small amount of electrodes through the nerves to see if the nerves are transmitting signals properly.; Lumbar puncture: This method is performed by the doctor placing electrodes on the patient's skin. They then pulse a small amount of electrodes through the nerves to see if the nerves are transmitting signals properly.
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): The doctor may also ask the patient to have an MRI to see if there is anything pressing on the nerve, such as a herniated disc or tumor.; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): The doctor may also ask the patient for an MRI to see if there is anything pressing on the nerve, such as a herniated disc or tumor.

Treatment methods for peripheral neuropathy
Treatment is based on treating the underlying disorder. For example, if diabetes is the cause, good blood sugar control is needed. If a vitamin deficiency is the cause, it can be treated by supplementing the missing vitamins... Many treatments can help relieve symptoms and return the person to daily activities. Sometimes, combining treatment methods can provide the best treatment results.
Pain relievers: Over-the-counter (OTC) pain relievers such as acetaminophen (Tylenol) and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as aspirin and ibuprofen can help control moderate pain. But if the patient takes too much, these drugs can negatively affect liver or stomach function. Therefore, patients need to use it as directed and should not use it for a long time, especially for those who often drink alcohol.; Pain relievers: Over-the-counter (OTC) pain relievers such as acetaminophen (Tylenol) and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as aspirin and ibuprofen can help control moderate pain. But if the patient takes too much, these drugs can negatively affect liver or stomach function. Therefore, patients need to use it as directed and should not use it for a long time, especially for those who often drink alcohol.
Prescription medications: Many prescription pain medications can also help control pain caused by peripheral neuropathy, such as some anti-seizure medications and some antidepressants. Additionally, other prescription medications include: Cyclooxygenase-2 inhibitors; tramadol; corticosteroid injections; seizure medication such as gabapentin or pregabalin; antidepressants such as amitriptyline; Cymbalta (a serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor); Prescription medications for sexual dysfunction in men include: sildenafil (Viagra); vardenafil (Levitra, Staxyn); tadalafil (Cialis); avanafil (Stendra).; Prescription medications: Many prescription pain medications can also help control pain caused by peripheral neuropathy, such as some anti-seizure medications and some antidepressants. Additionally, other prescription medications include: Cyclooxygenase-2 inhibitors; tramadol; corticosteroid injections; seizure medication such as gabapentin or pregabalin; antidepressants such as amitriptyline; Cymbalta (a serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor); Prescription medications for sexual dysfunction in men include: sildenafil (Viagra); vardenafil (Levitra, Staxyn); tadalafil (Cialis); avanafil (Stendra).
Plasmapheresis: This is a medical treatment to control the symptoms of peripheral neuropathy. This transfusion method helps remove potentially irritating antibodies from the blood. If the patient has a nerve block, the doctor will inject anesthetic directly into the nerve to treat the disease.; Plasmapheresis: This is a medical treatment to control the symptoms of peripheral neuropathy. This transfusion method helps remove potentially irritating antibodies from the blood. If the patient has a nerve block, the doctor will inject anesthetic directly into the nerve to treat the disease.
Transcutaneous electronic nerve stimulation (TENS): During TENS, electrodes placed on the skin transmit a small amount of electricity into the skin. The goal of this treatment is to interrupt the nerves that transmit pain signals to the brain.; Transcutaneous electronic nerve stimulation (TENS): During TENS, electrodes placed on the skin transmit a small amount of electricity into the skin. The goal of this treatment is to interrupt the nerves that transmit pain signals to the brain.
Cast or splint: this method can help improve peripheral neuropathy in the legs and arms.; Casting or splinting: this method can help improve peripheral neuropathy in the legs and arms.
Other treatment support methods: In addition, patients can apply a number of methods to help reduce symptoms of peripheral neuropathy such as: Chiropractic care; Acupuncture; Massage; meditation; yoga or regular, gentle exercise; Other treatment support methods: In addition, patients can apply a number of methods to help reduce symptoms of peripheral neuropathy such as: Chiropractic care; Acupuncture; Massage; meditation; yoga or regular, gentle exercise.
Surgical methods: In peripheral neuropathy surgery, depending on the specific case, there are methods: Decompressing surrounding organizations that cause nerve compression, thereby helping to reduce pain and improve sensation. Connecting, grafting and transferring nerves: in nerve plexus damage helps restore arm nerves to improve arm activities, minimal activities in daily activities; Surgical methods: In peripheral neuropathy surgery, depending on the specific case, there are methods: Decompressing surrounding organizations that cause nerve compression, thereby helping to reduce pain and improve sensation. Connecting, grafting and transferring nerves: in nerve plexus damage helps restore arm nerves to improve arm activities, minimal activities in daily activities; Decompression of surrounding organizations causing nerve compression, thereby helping to reduce pain and improve sensation.; Connecting, grafting and transferring nerves: in nerve plexus injuries helps restore arm nerves to improve arm activities, minimal activities in daily activities
Doctor Vo Don noted that patients should quit alcohol and cigarettes (if currently using). Both alcohol and tobacco worsen peripheral neuropathy and can cause nerve damage with long-term use. At the same time, patients need to pay attention to staying safe to avoid accidents due to loss of balance or loss of sensation caused by peripheral neuropathy such as:
Do not go barefoot; There are no obstacles in the house; Check the temperature of the bathtub or dishwater with your elbow, not your hand or foot.; Install handrails in the bathtub or shower.; Use anti-slip bath mats.; Do not stay in one position for too long. Instead, the patient should stand up and walk around a few times every hour.
Over-the-counter pain relievers such as acetaminophen can help control moderate pain caused by peripheral neuropathy.

Preventive measures for peripheral neuropathy
The best way to prevent peripheral neuropathy is to control its causes, such as diabetes, alcoholism or rheumatoid arthritis. Besides, people need to practice a healthy lifestyle including:
Eat a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains and lean proteins to keep the nerves healthy.; Fight vitamin B-12 deficiency by eating meat, fish, eggs, low-fat dairy foods, and fortified cereals. If you are vegetarian or vegan, fortified cereals are a good source of vitamin B-12, but you can also talk to your doctor about taking vitamin B-12 pills.; Exercise regularly, at least 30 minutes - 1 hour/each session and exercise at least 3 times/week.; Avoid factors that can cause nerve damage, including repetitive movements, cramped positions that put pressure on the nerves, exposure to toxic chemicals, smoking, and drinking too much alcohol.

Frequently asked questions about peripheral neuropathy
1. Is it okay to delay treatment for peripheral neuropathy?
Peripheral neuropathy can worsen over time if left untreated, such as causing muscle atrophy, irreversible limb weakness, and reduced or loss of sensation in the skin areas that the peripheral nerves control. When 85% of the nerves have been damaged, it is very difficult to treat effectively and the chance of recovery is almost zero. Therefore, as soon as patients notice suspicious symptoms, they should go to the hospital for examination. for early diagnosis and treatment.
2. Why do pain symptoms appear for a while and then disappear on their own?
Some acute neurological diseases have symptoms that suddenly appear and then disappear. But after a while, the pain may return with more severe symptoms. This type of neuropathy is called chronic insidious progressive polyneuropathy. Sometimes, patients who increase their activity level will experience more burning.
3. How can I control the burning sensation in my feet and legs?
Many patients find relief from burning pain by using topical creams or Lidocaine patches.
Peripheral neuropathy can cause serious complications that affect appearance and long-term health, especially in people with diabetes. If treated properly, as well as well-managed risk factors/conditions, the patient will have a chance to recover and avoid unfortunate complications such as amputation in neurological diseases. Peripheral due to diabetes. For healthy people, in addition to practicing a healthy lifestyle, eating and living, you should have regular health check-ups to screen and help detect and treat diseases early.
Department of Neurology, Tam Anh General Hospital is a reputable unit for examining and treating neurological diseases, including facial paralysis. With a team of leading experts and doctors, skilled and experienced, and equipped with top modern machinery and medical equipment systems, we will help diagnose and treat diseases on target, bringing effective results. high, reducing costs for patients.

A deficiency of these vitamins in the body can cause peripheral neuropathy; Vitamin deficiency: B vitamins, especially vitamins B1, B6, B12; vitamin E and niacin are important for nerve health. A deficiency in these vitamins in the body can cause peripheral neuropathy.
However, in some cases, even with extensive evaluation, the cause of peripheral neuropathy in some people remains unknown – this is called idiopathic neuropathy.

Before diagnosing peripheral neuropathy, your doctor will review your medical history and conduct a physical exam to evaluate your nerves. After a neurological evaluation, depending on the symptoms and results of the neurological evaluation, the patient may have other tests that help the doctor determine the type of peripheral neuropathy including:

For this test, the doctor will place a small needle into the patient's muscle. Then, the doctor will ask the patient to gently move the muscles. subsections.subsection_content:
Treatment is based on treating the underlying disorder. For example, if diabetes is the cause, good blood sugar control is needed. If a vitamin deficiency is the cause, it can be treated by supplementing the missing vitamins... Many treatments can help relieve symptoms and return the person to daily activities. Sometimes, combining treatment methods can provide the best treatment results.
Pain relievers: Over-the-counter (OTC) pain relievers such as acetaminophen (Tylenol) and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as aspirin and ibuprofen can help control moderate pain. But if the patient takes too much, these drugs can negatively affect liver or stomach function. Therefore, patients need to use it as directed and should not use it for a long time, especially for those who often drink alcohol.; Pain relievers: Over-the-counter (OTC) pain relievers such as acetaminophen (Tylenol) and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as aspirin and ibuprofen can help control moderate pain. But if the patient takes too much, these drugs can negatively affect liver or stomach function. Therefore, patients need to use it as directed and should not use it for a long time, especially for those who often drink alcohol.
Prescription medications: Many prescription pain medications can also help control pain caused by peripheral neuropathy, such as some anti-seizure medications and some antidepressants. Additionally, other prescription medications include: Cyclooxygenase-2 inhibitors; tramadol; corticosteroid injections; seizure medication such as gabapentin or pregabalin; antidepressants such as amitriptyline; Cymbalta (a serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor); Prescription medications for sexual dysfunction in men include: sildenafil (Viagra); vardenafil (Levitra, Staxyn); tadalafil (Cialis); avanafil (Stendra).; Prescription medications: Many prescription pain medications can also help control pain caused by peripheral neuropathy, such as some anti-seizure medications and some antidepressants. Additionally, other prescription medications include: Cyclooxygenase-2 inhibitors; tramadol; corticosteroid injections; seizure medication such as gabapentin or pregabalin; antidepressants such as amitriptyline; Cymbalta (a serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor); Prescription medications for sexual dysfunction in men include: sildenafil (Viagra); vardenafil (Levitra, Staxyn); tadalafil (Cialis); avanafil (Stendra).
Plasmapheresis: This is a medical treatment to control the symptoms of peripheral neuropathy. This transfusion method helps remove potentially irritating antibodies from the blood. If the patient has a nerve block, the doctor will inject anesthetic directly into the nerve to treat the disease.; Plasmapheresis: This is a medical treatment to control the symptoms of peripheral neuropathy. This transfusion method helps remove potentially irritating antibodies from the blood. If the patient has a nerve block, the doctor will inject anesthetic directly into the nerve to treat the disease.
Transcutaneous electronic nerve stimulation (TENS): During TENS, electrodes placed on the skin transmit a small amount of electricity into the skin. The goal of this treatment is to interrupt the nerves that transmit pain signals to the brain.; Transcutaneous electronic nerve stimulation (TENS): During TENS, electrodes placed on the skin transmit a small amount of electricity into the skin. The goal of this treatment is to interrupt the nerves that transmit pain signals to the brain.
Cast or splint: this method can help improve peripheral neuropathy in the legs and arms.; Casting or splinting: this method can help improve peripheral neuropathy in the legs and arms.
Other treatment support methods: In addition, patients can apply a number of methods to help reduce symptoms of peripheral neuropathy such as: Chiropractic care; Acupuncture; Massage; meditation; yoga or regular, gentle exercise; Other treatment support methods: In addition, patients can apply a number of methods to help reduce symptoms of peripheral neuropathy such as: Chiropractic care; Acupuncture; Massage; meditation; yoga or regular, gentle exercise.
Surgical methods: In peripheral neuropathy surgery, depending on the specific case, there are methods: Decompressing surrounding organizations that cause nerve compression, thereby helping to reduce pain and improve sensation. Connecting, grafting and transferring nerves: in nerve plexus damage helps restore arm nerves to improve arm activities, minimal activities in daily activities; Surgical methods: In peripheral neuropathy surgery, depending on the specific case, there are methods: Decompressing surrounding organizations that cause nerve compression, thereby helping to reduce pain and improve sensation. Connecting, grafting and transferring nerves: in nerve plexus damage helps restore arm nerves to improve arm activities, minimal activities in daily activities; Decompression of surrounding organizations causing nerve compression, thereby helping to reduce pain and improve sensation.; Connecting, grafting and transferring nerves: in nerve plexus injuries helps restore arm nerves to improve arm activities, minimal activities in daily activities
Doctor Vo Don noted that patients should quit alcohol and cigarettes (if currently using). Both alcohol and tobacco worsen peripheral neuropathy and can cause nerve damage with long-term use. At the same time, patients need to pay attention to staying safe to avoid accidents due to loss of balance or loss of sensation caused by peripheral neuropathy such as:
Do not go barefoot; There are no obstacles in the house; Check the temperature of the bathtub or dishwater with your elbow, not your hand or foot.; Install handrails in the bathtub or shower.; Use anti-slip bath mats.; Do not stay in one position for too long. Instead, the patient should stand up and walk around a few times every hour.
Over-the-counter pain relievers such as acetaminophen can help control moderate pain caused by peripheral neuropathy.

subsections.subsection_content:
The best way to prevent peripheral neuropathy is to control its causes, such as diabetes, alcoholism or rheumatoid arthritis. Besides, people need to practice a healthy lifestyle including:
Eat a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains and lean proteins to keep the nerves healthy.; Fight vitamin B-12 deficiency by eating meat, fish, eggs, low-fat dairy foods, and fortified cereals. If you are vegetarian or vegan, fortified cereals are a good source of vitamin B-12, but you can also talk to your doctor about taking vitamin B-12 pills.; Exercise regularly, at least 30 minutes - 1 hour/each session and exercise at least 3 times/week.; Avoid factors that can cause nerve damage, including repetitive movements, cramped positions that put pressure on the nerves, exposure to toxic chemicals, smoking, and drinking too much alcohol.

subsections.subsection_name: Frequently asked questions about peripheral neuropathy
subsections.subsection_content:
1. Is it okay to delay treatment for peripheral neuropathy?
Peripheral neuropathy can worsen over time if left untreated, such as causing muscle atrophy, irreversible limb weakness, and reduced or loss of sensation in the skin areas that the peripheral nerves control. When 85% of the nerves have been damaged, it is very difficult to treat effectively and the chance of recovery is almost zero. Therefore, as soon as patients notice suspicious symptoms, they should go to the hospital for examination. for early diagnosis and treatment.
2. Why do pain symptoms appear for a while and then disappear on their own?
Some acute neurological diseases have symptoms that suddenly appear and then disappear. But after a while, the pain may return with more severe symptoms. This type of neuropathy is called chronic insidious progressive polyneuropathy. Sometimes, patients who increase their activity level will experience more burning.
3. How can I control the burning sensation in my feet and legs?
Many patients find relief from burning pain by using topical creams or Lidocaine patches.
Peripheral neuropathy can cause serious complications that affect appearance and long-term health, especially in people with diabetes. If treated properly, as well as well-managed risk factors/conditions, the patient will have a chance to recover and avoid unfortunate complications such as amputation in neurological diseases. Peripheral due to diabetes. For healthy people, in addition to practicing a healthy lifestyle, eating and living, you should have regular health check-ups to screen and help detect and treat diseases early.
